questions: Classify resources on the basis of exhaustibility. Mention four features of each.
answers: On the basis of exhaustibility, there are two types of resources :  Renewable resources  Non-renewable resources  Renewable resources :  They can be renewed or obtained even after they are used.  They are not exhaustible due to constant use.  They are affected by external environment.  For example : solar and wind energy.  Non-renewable resources :  They can’t be reproduced once they are used.  They are exhaustible due to continuous use.  They are free from environmental effects.  For example : minerals and fossil fuels.

questions: Explain reasource planning. What are the steps involved in resource planning ?  Or 		Why is resource planning essential in India ?  Or 		What is resource planning ? Why is resource planning essential ? Explain it with three reasons.
answers: Resource planning is a technique or skill for proper utilization of resources.  As resources are limited, their planning is necessary so that we can use them properly and also save them for our future generations.  Resources are not only limited but they are distributed over different parts of the country.  Resource planning is also essential for production of resources and to protect them from over exploitation.

International Resources : There are international institutions which regulate some resource. questions: ‘Indiscriminate use of resources had led to numerous problems.’ Justify this statement. 		 [Board Term 1, KVS-2014,  2012,
answers: Ans.		 Resources are vital for human survival and it was believed that resources are free gift of nature. The indiscriminate use of resources led to the following problems :  To satisfy the greed of few individuals, depletion of resources were continued.  Due to the accumulation of resources in few hands, the society gets divided into two segments, i.e., rich and poor.  Indiscriminate use of resources led to ecological crises, e.g., ozone layer depletion, land degradation, global warming and environmental pollution.
